label: Timer
info: Send the output of a `suncalc` node once per minute to the _Theme_ and _Time of Day_ subflows (q.v.) The output of each subflow is sent as a retained MQTT message to drive lighting and window covering automation.

label: Chez Nous Main
info: Helper subroutine flows for accessing the Hue Bridge API on Chez Nous Main.

meta.author: parasaurolophus <apps@rader.us>
meta.desc: Make a HomeKit switch simulate a button

name: Hue Send
info:
Send a message to the API (version 2) on a given Hue Bridge.

See <https://developers.meethue.com/develop/hue-api-v2/> for details.

# Configuration

`ADDRESS` environment variable is the bridge's IP address.

`KEY` environment variable is the client access token for the message.

# Input

`msg.topic` is the API URI, e.g. `/resource`, `/room/0ca8f049-7ac9-4872-8069-4770834e4f11` etc.

`msg.payload` is the message body, if any.

`msg.method` is the HTTP request method, e.g. `GET`, `PUT` etc.

# Outputs

If successful, the HTTP response will be sent as a parsed JSON object from output 1.

A standard Node-RED error message will be sent on output 2 if the `http request` node throws an exception.

meta.author: parasaurolophus <apps@rader.us>
meta.desc: Send a command to the Hue Bridge API

name: Hue Access Token
info:
Use the Hue Bridge API to create a client access token.

**Invoke this subflow within 30 seconds of pressing the button on top of the bridge. Watch the debug console output to see the response. If successful, you will see the generated key among the response payload's properties.**

See <https://developers.meethue.com/develop/hue-api-v2/getting-started/> for details.

# Configuration

`ADDRESS` environment variable is the bridge's IP address.

`USERNAME` environment variable is the client "user name" for which a key is being requested.

# Input

Incoming message is ignored.

# Outputs

The HTTP response will be sent as a parsed JSON object. If successful, look for the value of the `msg.payload.success.username` property in the output. That is the string you should use as the access token header in all subsequent Hue Bridge API request messages.

meta.author: parasaurolophus <apps@rader.us>
meta.desc: Invoke the Hue Bridge API for registering a client

name: Hue Group Metadata
info: Extract and consolidate metadata for a room or a zone. Note that from an API point of view, the only difference between rooms and zones is the URI used to access them.

meta.author: parasaurolophus <apps@rader.us>
meta.desc: Extract and reformat frequently used Hue metadata for rooms and "zones"

name: PowerView Scenes
info:
Use the _Hunter Douglas PowerView_® hub API to get metadata for scenes.


See <https://motorisation.hde.nl/hd/powerview/general-guides/API/> for details.

# Configuration

The `ADDRESS` environment variable must be configured with the IP address of the hub.

# Input

All input message properties are ignored but care should be taken not to pass any through that could affect the behavior of a `http request` node in unintended ways.

# Output

HTTP response from the hub.

meta.author: parasaurolophus <apps@rader.us>
meta.desc: Get the scene configuration from a PowerView hub

name: PowerView Set Scene
info:
Use the _Hunter Douglas PowerView_® hub API to activate a given window shade scene.


See <https://motorisation.hde.nl/hd/powerview/general-guides/API/> for details.

# Configuration

The `ADDRESS` environment variable must be configured with the IP address of the hub.

# Input

`msg.payload` containing the id of the scene to activate.

All other input message properties are ignored but care should be taken not to pass any through that could affect the behavior of a `http request` node in unintended ways.

# Output

HTTP response from the hub.

# Side Effects

If successful, the window shades will move to the settings defined by the specified scene as configured using the _PowerView_® mobile app.

meta.author: parasaurolophus <apps@rader.us>
meta.desc: Extract Hue metadata used to author dashboard and HomeKit integration

name: Time of Day
info:
Determine the time of day based on the latest `suncalc` event. This will be one of the following values:

| `msg.payload` | Time of Day |
|:-:|-|
| `morning` | Sunrise to 5 hours after sunrise |
| `midday` | 5 hours after sunrise to 5 hours before sunset |
| `afternoon` | 5 hours before sunset to sunset |
| `evening` | Sunset to bedtime |
| `night` | Bedtime to sunrise |

"Bedtime" is configurable using the dashboard. The actual time at which `evening` transitions to `night` varies from day to day by adding a randomly generated offset from 30 minutes before to 30 minutes after the configured time. A new random offset is generated each morning.

name: Theme
info:
Use the most recent `suncalc` event to determine the theme for lighting automation based on the current month and day. This will be one of the following:

| `msg.payload` | Current Date                     |
|:-------------:|----------------------------------|
| `tribal`      | July 1 - 4 |
| `spooky`      | Any day in October               |
| `jolly`       | Any day in December              |
| `standard`    | Any other day                    |

name: Filter Timer Events
info:
Pass messages through if and only if all of the following conditions are met:

1. `global.enableAutomation` is `true`
2. Payload has changed since last event
3. This is not the first event since the flow was started

name: Get Global Bedtime
info: Set `msg.payload` to the current value of `global.bedtime.minutes`

name: Yard Evening
info: Set `msg.theme` to the current value of `global.theme`. Select which output on which to forward the message based on the current theme.
